dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The concept of having two jobs, like a double helix in your career DNA—it's fascinating.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The concept of having two jobs, like a double helix in your career D N A-it's fascinating.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's not just a metaphor. Job No. 1 is all about being other-centered, right? Like, asking "How can I be most helpful?" instead of just chasing your own agenda.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's not just a metaphor. Job No. one is all about being other-centered, right? Like, asking How can I be most helpful? instead of just chasing your own agenda.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Job no. 1 forces you to value relationships and be other-centered. Instead of thinking first about your own self-interest, you think first about the interests of others: clients, peers, and even your boss.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And that mindset, um, actually makes you more valuable to clients—you're serving their interests, not just pushing products they don't need.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And that mindset, um, actually makes you more valuable to clients-you're serving their interests, not just pushing products they don't need.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, with clients, you become a person who serves their interests, instead of a pushy, aggressive type who is always selling something they don't need.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then there's Job No. 2, which, you know, pays the bills. It's easy for altruistic people to neglect that part, like getting sidetracked helping neighbors find a lost cat instead of preparing for a critical meeting.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then there's Job No. two, which, you know, pays the bills. It's easy for altruistic people to neglect that part, like getting sidetracked helping neighbors find a lost cat instead of preparing for a critical meeting.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Instead of organizing that critical meeting, they end up spending all morning calling neighbors to see if anyone spotted the lost cat that may - or may not - have been wandering on the edge of their neighborhood.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm, and the text mentions how some people forget their own agenda entirely. But the real insight is that these two jobs don't compete; they complement each other.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm, and the text mentions how some people forget their own agenda entirely. But the real insight is that these two jobs don't compete; they complement each other.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Job no. 1 does not compete with job no. 2. Job no. 1 makes you much better at job no. 2.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right! Job No. 1 actually makes you better at Job No. 2. It builds stronger relationships and helps you see beyond your own narrow goals.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! Job No. one actually makes you better at Job No. two. It builds stronger relationships and helps you see beyond your own narrow goals.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Job no. 1 makes you much better at job no. 2. It builds stronger relationships.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Though it only works if you take Job No. 1 seriously on its own terms—not just helping people who can help you back. Otherwise, you come off as manipulative.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Though it only works if you take Job No. one seriously on its own terms-not just helping people who can help you back. Otherwise, you come off as manipulative.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If you only help people who can help you in job no. 2, you will soon be revealed as a superficial and somewhat manipulative person.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, like that person who's super helpful when you're useful to them, but ghosts you when you're not. We've all met that type.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, like that person who's super helpful when you're useful to them, but ghosts you when you're not. We've all met that type.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: You know the type... someone who is eager to help you when you have a big job, but who won't return your phone calls when you are looking for a job.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, so the key is investing equal energy in both. Even making to-do lists for each, like the article suggests.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, so the key is investing equal energy in both. Even making to-do lists for each, like the article suggests.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Take both jobs seriously. Invest equal energy in each.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And reviewing your performance in both roles regularly—weekly, monthly, yearly. Because success isn't just financial; some rewards feed your soul.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And reviewing your performance in both roles regularly-weekly, monthly, yearly. Because success isn't just financial; some rewards feed your soul.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the end of each week, month, and year analyze your performance and achievements in both positions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Brian Kasanoff really drives home that narrow vision isn't enough. Your purpose is bigger than just paying bills.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Brian Kasanoff really drives home that narrow vision isn't enough. Your purpose is bigger than just paying bills.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's a refreshing way to structure your career mindset, honestly. Puts meaning back into the daily grind.
